Hermes bringing the Infant Dionysos to Papposilenos and the nymphs of Nysa.
Zeus shows himself to his mortal lover Semele, the mother of Dionysus, in his true form as a lightning bolt, and she is burned to ashes; one version of the myth has Hermes take Dionysus, the unborn son of Semele and Zeus, from the ashes and deliver him to Nymphs to be reared.

Calyx Krater with the Story of Cadmus
In order to Python Painterdo so, he tries to draw water from a spring in the vicinity, but a snake of Ares guards the water. The snake kills many of Cadmus’ men, but Cadmus eventually defeats the beast
Meeting of Oedipus and the Sphinx
Oedipus and the Sphinx.

After he is restored to life, Pelops leaves Asia Minor to go to Elis in the Peloponnese (named after Pelops) in order to win the hand of Hippodamia, the daughter of king Oenomaus. In order to win Hippodamia, he has to defeat the king in a chariot race. Thirteen suitors fail before he wins, and when the king caught a suitor, he killed him. In order to win, Pelops is said in different versions of the myth either to have had help from Poseidon, or to have bribed Oenomaus’charioteer Myrtilus to take the linchpins from the wheels of the Oenomaus’ chariot. King Oenomaus crashes and dies during the pursuit
Clytemnestra (Wife) Hesitating to Strike Agamemnon in His Sleep (For sacrificing their daughter), Her Accomplice, Presses Her
Clytemnestra (Wife of Agamemnon) killing Cassandra (Agamemnon's side chick)

Orestes killing Aigisthos
Agaememnon’s son Orestes was away during the murder and, learning of his father’s fate, returns to Mycenae to take revenge. With the help of his sister Electra, he enters the palace and murders both Aegisthus and his own mother Clytemnestra
Apollo Purifies Orestes with the Blood of a Piglet

Blinding of Polyphemus.
Odysseus sharpens a wooden stake, heats it in the fire and then drives it through the Cyclops’ one eye with the help of his companions.
Odysseus Escaping from Polyphemus' Cave under the Belly of a Ram

Odysseus next sails to the land of the Laestrygonians, a savage group who sink all of Odysseus’ ships except for his own and eat the crews.

Odysseus Companion Changed into Swine
Circe is a witch connected to the East (she is a descendant of the sun). She first turns Odysseus’ men into pigs, except for Eurylochus who reports what has happened.

Perseus and Andromeda
An oracle told Cepheus that the monster would only be appeased if he should offer his daughter Andromeda to it, and he chains her to a rock (a myth which we will see in a future chapter that is very similar to a story told of the great hero Hercules). Perseus kills the beast and marries Andromeda

Another version of Hera’s anger has the goddess send a pair of snakes to kill Heracles just after he is born. Heracles, however, is up to this challenge, even as an infant, and strangles the snakes as they attack him

Heracles goes to the land of the Hyperboreans, at the ends of the earth in the far north, to fetch the beast.

Herakles Cleaning the Stables of Augeus, the son of Helios, the king of Elis

Heracles and the Stymphalian Brids
these deadly birds which killed men, all flocked together at a lake in Arcadia called Stymphalus. Heracles shoots them with arrows.
Heracles and the Cretan Bull
Heracles (in some versions with the help of an army) tames the man-eatting mares by feeding Diomedes himself to them. He brings them to Eurystheus, who sets them free.

Hippolyta is the queen of the Amazons, a fierce tribe of powerful and savage warrior women who live at the northern edges of the world. Heracles had to get her girdle. He defeats her in battle and takes it.
Geryon lived on the island of Erythia in the far west of the Mediterranean. He had three bodies and tended a herd of cattle, helped by a giant Eurytion and a two-headed dog Orthus.
The Hesperides are the three daughters of Night guarded a tree which produced golden apples which a great serpent, Ladon, protected.
Hercules and Cerberus

Hercules and Achelous
Achelous, who had horns and could change into different shapes (a task which recalls his wrestling match with Nereus during his search for the apples of the Hesperides.

The Harpies were winged creatures who swept down and took Phineus’ food when he tried to eat, leaving him only a small and putrid smelling morsel with which to sustain himself. The Argonauts Zetes and Calais, winged sons of the north wind Boreas, chase the Harpies and defeat them.
Medea, Jason's ex-wife (due to divorce) kills her own children as revenge against Jason
Aeneas leave Troy, taking his crippled father Anchises with him on his back.

Death of Dido
Aeneas (lover) leaves because Hermes told him to move on. she kills herself with a sword that Aeneas had given her.
Romulus and Remus (after being abandoned) were saved by a wolf, who suckled them and then found by Faustulus, a shepherd of Amulius, who raised them.
Romulus and Remus  and the she-wolf
The Sabine Women Bring Peace between the Romans and Sabines

Rape of the Sabine Women
Romulus therefore brings women to his city through violence and trickery. He invites the Sabines to a festival, but when they come, the Romans take many of the women, thereby starting a war.

The two Titans endure the punishments of Zeus: Atlas holds up the star-studded heavens and helplessly watches the vulture (or eagle) attack his brother, Prometheus, who is bound to a column.
Prometheus ignoring vulture gazes into the future knowing that he will be released and Zeus will be defeated

Both Semele and Zeus are shown under extreme emotion—she, as death approaches, and he, rising from her couch with pity and horror, knowing her coming agony.
Pan pursues a herdsman, possibly Daphnis, son of Hermes. Pan's intentions are clear, and his lust is wittily echoed by the herm (or, more likely, figure of Priapus) in the rocky background.
Triptolemus holds stalks of grain in his left hand and in his right hand a dish (phiale), into which Persephone pours liquid from the jug in her right hand
Orpheus and Eurydice with a snake approaching

Jason Is Disgorged by the Dragon that Guards the Golden Fleece. Athena (not Medea) watches the bearded dragon disgorge Jason
